content.title: Ischemic Colitis
content.summary: Ischemic colitis is the most common form of intestinal ischemia, resulting from transient reduction in colonic blood flow. It typically affects the watershed areas (splenic flexure, rectosigmoid junction) in elderly patients with atherosclerosis. Most cases are non-gangrenous and self-limited, but severe cases may progress to gangrene requiring surgical intervention.
key_points: Most common form of intestinal ischemia; typically affects elderly with atherosclerosis
Watershed areas most vulnerable: splenic flexure, rectosigmoid junction
Classic triad: crampy abdominal pain, urgent defecation, bloody diarrhea within 24 hours
CT: segmental colonic wall thickening, thumbprinting; colonoscopy: edema, hemorrhagic mucosa, ulceration
Most cases (80-85%) are non-gangrenous and self-limited; supportive treatment
Surgery for peritonitis, perforation, gangrene, or clinical deterioration despite treatment
content.statement: Ischemic colitis is usually a self-limited condition requiring supportive care, but clinicians must recognize warning signs of gangrene or perforation that necessitate surgical intervention.

explanation.intuition: The colon receives blood from the SMA (right/transverse) and IMA (left/sigmoid). Watershed areas at the boundaries of these vascular territories (splenic flexure, rectosigmoid) are most susceptible to ischemia during low-flow states. Unlike acute mesenteric ischemia (arterial occlusion), ischemic colitis usually results from transient hypoperfusion in patients with underlying vascular disease.
explanation.key_insight: Ischemic colitis should be distinguished from acute mesenteric ischemia (small bowel, more severe, higher mortality). Right-sided ischemic colitis (SMA territory) is a more severe variant with higher mortality. The rectum is typically spared because of dual blood supply from IMA and internal iliac artery.
explanation.technical_details: Diagnosis: CT with IV contrast shows segmental wall thickening, 'thumbprinting' (submucosal hemorrhage/edema), pericolonic stranding. Colonoscopy (after stabilization) shows edematous pale mucosa, submucosal hemorrhage, ulceration; biopsies show mucosal necrosis. Severity: mild (mucosal), moderate (muscular), severe (transmural/gangrenous).

definitions_glossary.ischemic_colitis: Colonic injury from reduced blood flow, typically in watershed areas; most common form of intestinal ischemia
definitions_glossary.watershed_areas: Vascular boundary zones between SMA and IMA territories: splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction
definitions_glossary.thumbprinting: Radiographic sign of submucosal edema/hemorrhage appearing as rounded indentations on contrast studies or CT
definitions_glossary.gangrenous_colitis: Transmural ischemia with necrosis; requires surgical intervention
definitions_glossary.non_occlusive_mesenteric_ischemia: NOMI: intestinal ischemia from low-flow state without vessel occlusion
definitions_glossary.acute_mesenteric_ischemia: Arterial occlusion of SMA causing small bowel ischemia; more severe than ischemic colitis
definitions_glossary.low_flow_state: Systemic hypoperfusion from heart failure, shock, or hypotension causing ischemia
definitions_glossary.segmental_colitis: Inflammation limited to segment of colon; pattern in ischemic colitis
definitions_glossary.colon_single_stripe_sign: Linear ulceration along antimesenteric border on colonoscopy; classic for ischemic colitis
definitions_glossary.reversible_ischemia: Non-gangrenous ischemic colitis that heals with supportive care
definitions_glossary.stricture_formation: Late complication of ischemic colitis from fibrosis during healing
definitions_glossary.ischemic_proctitis: Rare; rectal ischemia usually from radiation or rectal surgery (rectum normally protected by dual supply)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Ischemic colitis results from transient reduction in colonic blood flow, often in the setting of systemic hypotension, cardiac arrhythmia, or low-flow states in patients with underlying atherosclerosis. Watershed areas are most vulnerable. Reperfusion after ischemia contributes to injury through reactive oxygen species. Severity depends on duration and degree of ischemia.
key_pathways: Low-flow state + atherosclerosis → reduced colonic perfusion
Watershed areas most susceptible → splenic flexure, rectosigmoid
Mucosal ischemia → edema, hemorrhage → crampy pain, bloody diarrhea
Prolonged/severe ischemia → transmural necrosis → gangrene, perforation
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Most cases are self-limited (80-85%), but gangrenous ischemic colitis has high mortality (50%). Right-sided involvement suggests more severe ischemia and worse prognosis. Early recognition of peritonitis is critical.

imaging.location: Typically left-sided (splenic flexure, descending, sigmoid); right-sided is more severe

colonoscopy.timing: After hemodynamic stabilization; within 48 hours if possible
colonoscopy.biopsy: Mucosal necrosis, hemorrhage, crypt withering; distinguishes from IBD

severity_grading.moderate: Ulceration without transmural necrosis; may stricture

surgical_intervention.procedure: Segmental colectomy with diversion (Hartmann procedure) or primary anastomosis depending on patient stability

long_term.follow_up: Colonoscopy in 1-2 weeks to assess healing; later if stricture suspected

skos.definition: Colonic injury resulting from inadequate blood flow, typically affecting watershed areas, presenting with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea, and usually self-limited in non-gangrenous cases

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic presentation of ischemic colitis
Identify watershed areas of the colon and their vulnerability to ischemia
Interpret CT and colonoscopy findings in ischemic colitis
Differentiate non-gangrenous from gangrenous ischemic colitis
clinical_pearls: Classic triad: crampy pain → urgent defecation → bloody diarrhea within 24 hours
Rectum usually spared (dual supply from IMA and internal iliac)
Right-sided ischemic colitis = worse prognosis; think SMA disease
Most cases self-limited; surgery only for gangrene/peritonitis/perforation
Single stripe sign on colonoscopy = linear ulcer along antimesenteric border
Distinguish from acute mesenteric ischemia: IC is colonic, milder, usually self-limited
common_misconceptions: All mesenteric ischemia is the same (IC is distinct from acute mesenteric ischemia)
Antibiotics are always required (controversial; used but benefit unproven)
Colonoscopy should be avoided (safe after stabilization; aids diagnosis)

citations.title: ACG Clinical Guideline: Epidemiology, Risk Factors, Patterns of Presentation, Diagnosis, and Management of Colon Ischemia

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on ACG clinical guideline on colon ischemia
